title: Disease X: Scientists identify prevention strategy; urge preparedness - The Times of India
mainText:
A new strategy for disease X prevention

There is a big fear called Disease X, in the global health field. It is an unknown pathogen that could cause a serious global outbreak. As the globe struggles to contain the COVID-19 pandemic and faces the prospect of more outbreaks, scientists are investigating novel approaches to illness prevention. One of these strategies is a paradigm change in how we view bats, who have long been demonised as disease carriers. Here we will learn more about Disease X and consider how peaceful coexistence with bats may revolutionise efforts to prevent pandemics.

What is disease X?

Disease X, as designated by the World Health Organization (WHO), represents a hypothetical pathogen with the potential to cause a global health crisis. While the current priority diseases include familiar ones like COVID-19 and Ebola, Disease X symbolises the threat of an unknown adversary. With the majority of emerging infectious diseases originating from animals, vigilance and surveillance are crucial in identifying and monitoring potential sources of Pathogen X.

The role of bats in disease transmission

Contrary to popular belief, bats are not the enemy in the fight against pandemics; they are, in fact, essential players in ecosystem balance. However, disturbances to bat habitats and activities such as hunting and consumption increase the risk of zoonotic spillover events, where pathogens leap from animals to humans. Recognising bats as reservoirs for various viruses, including those closely related to Disease X, underlines the urgency of preserving their habitats and minimising human-bat interactions.

Preserving bat habitats

Peacefully coexisting with bats is a novel strategy proposed by researchers from the Wildlife Conservation Society and Cornell University to prevent future pandemics. Their research, which was published in 'The Lancet Planetary Health,' refutes the widespread belief that bats are disease carriers and suggests that humans avoid upsetting them. Researchers advocate for a shift towards preserving bat habitats as a proactive measure in pandemic prevention. By minimising human interference in areas such as cave tourism and deforestation, we can reduce the likelihood of zoonotic transmission and safeguard public health. This approach not only protects biodiversity but also acknowledges the invaluable ecosystem services provided by bats, from insect control to pollination.

Addressing the root causes of pandemics necessitates systemic changes, including curbing the commercial wildlife trade and revisiting consumption habits. Mixing different animal species in markets creates fertile ground for pathogen transmission, as witnessed in previous outbreaks like SARS-CoV-2. Urgent behavioural shifts are required to mitigate these risks, with a focus on respecting wildlife and their ecological roles.

What should be the new approach?

In the face of mounting challenges posed by emerging infectious diseases, embracing a new approach to pandemic prevention is imperative. By establishing a taboo against disturbing bats and supporting conservation efforts, we can take proactive steps towards averting future pandemics at their source. While the path ahead may be uncertain, the benefits of preserving biodiversity and protecting public health make it a journey worth undertaking.

author: India Today Information Desk
title: National Protein Day: Significance and 5 protein-rich foods for your body's needs - India Today
mainText:
It's protein appreciation time! Did you know February 27 is National Protein Day? This day serves as a global reminder of the importance of this macronutrient in our diets. Let's delve into the reason behind this observance and explore 5 delicious protein powerhouses you can incorporate into your daily meals.

WHY CELEBRATE PROTEIN?
Protein is the building block of life. It's found in every cell of our body and plays a crucial role in numerous functions, including:

Muscle growth and repair: Essential for athletes and fitness enthusiasts, but also vital for maintaining everyday strength and mobility.
Tissue and bone health: Supports strong bones and helps prevent osteoporosis.
Enzyme and hormone production: Crucial for various bodily processes, from digestion to metabolism.
Immune system function: Keeps us healthy by fighting off infections and diseases.
MEETING YOUR PROTEIN NEEDS:
The recommended daily protein intake varies depending on age, activity level, and health conditions. Generally, adults need around 0.8 grams of protein per kilogram of body weight. Fortunately, various foods can help you achieve your protein goals.

5 PROTEIN-PACKED POWERHOUSES:
Lentils & Beans: These plant-based superstars are high in protein and fibre, making them a filling and affordable option. Explore varieties like chickpeas, black beans, and kidney beans in soups, stews, salads, and dips
Greek Yogurt: A creamy delight packed with protein and calcium. Enjoy it plain, with fruit, or use it as a base for dips and sauces
Eggs are a versatile and affordable source of protein, vitamins, and minerals. Enjoy them scrambled, poached, boiled, or even baked goods
Fatty Fish: Salmon, tuna, and sardines are rich in protein and omega-3 fatty acids, beneficial for heart and brain health. Aim for 2–3 servings per week
Nuts & Seeds: These tiny nutritional powerhouses are packed with protein, healthy fats, and fibre. Snack them directly, sprinkle them on salads or yogurt, or add them to smoothies and baked goods.
REMEMBER:
Balance is key: While protein is important, don't neglect other essential nutrients like fruits, vegetables, and whole grains for a well-rounded diet
Variety is important: Include protein sources from various food groups to ensure you're getting all the essential amino acids your body needs
Talk to a healthcare professional: If you have any concerns about your protein intake or specific dietary needs, consult a doctor or registered dietitian for personalised advice.
So, celebrate National Protein Day by understanding its importance and incorporating these delicious protein powerhouses into your diet! Your body will thank you for it.

title: 9 things to look for while buying multivitamins for women - The Times of India
mainText:
Multivitamins fill nutrient gaps in women

Women should consume multivitamins to ensure they meet their nutritional needs, especially during times of high physical demand such as pregnancy, breastfeeding, or menstruation. Multivitamins can help fill potential nutrient gaps in their diet, supporting overall health and well-being. They provide essential vitamins and minerals like calcium, iron, and folic acid, which are crucial for bone health, energy production, and preventing birth defects. Additionally, women often have specific nutrient requirements that may not be met through diet alone, making multivitamins a convenient and effective way to ensure optimal health and vitality.

How to choose the right multivitamin?

When it comes to choosing multivitamins for women, the options can be overwhelming. With shelves lined with various brands and formulations, it's essential to know what to look for to ensure you're making the right choice for your health needs. Here are a few points that can help you buying the right multivitamin.

Check the ingredients

Start by examining the list of ingredients. Look for a comprehensive blend of vitamins, minerals, and other nutrients tailored to women's health needs. Key nutrients to prioritize include vitamins A, C, D, E, K, B vitamins (such as B6, B12, and folate), calcium, magnesium, zinc, and iron. Ensure the product contains optimal levels of these nutrients to support overall health and wellbeing.

Consider the formulation of the multivitamin

Some products are designed specifically for women, taking into account their unique nutritional requirements, such as iron for menstrual health and calcium for bone strength. Look for formulations that address specific concerns, such as prenatal vitamins for women planning pregnancy or postnatal vitamins for new mothers.

Check the quality and purity

Choose multivitamins from reputable brands known for their commitment to quality and purity. Look for products that undergo rigorous testing and adhere to government standards to ensure safety, potency, and consistency. Third-party certifications can provide additional assurance of quality.

Buy only if it has a high bioavailability

Opt for multivitamins with high bioavailability, meaning the nutrients are easily absorbed and utilized by the body. Look for forms of vitamins and minerals that are well-absorbed, such as methylcobalamin (vitamin B12), methylfolate (folate), and chelated minerals (e.g., calcium citrate, magnesium glycinate). Enhanced absorption ensures maximum effectiveness and benefits.

Check what doses your body requires

Pay attention to the dosage of individual nutrients in the multivitamin. Ensure that the levels are appropriate for your age, gender, and specific health needs. Avoid products with excessive or insufficient amounts of nutrients, as this can lead to imbalances or deficiencies. Consult with a healthcare professional to determine the right dosage for you based on your health status and lifestyle.

Check for additional nutrients

Consider whether the multivitamin contains additional nutrients or botanical extracts that offer added health benefits. Look for ingredients like antioxidants (e.g., vitamin C, vitamin E, selenium), omega-3 fatty acids, probiotics, and botanicals (e.g., cranberry extract, green tea extract) that support immune function, cardiovascular health, digestive health, and more.

Allergens and additives

Check the label for common allergens and unnecessary additives. Choose multivitamins that are free from common allergens such as gluten, dairy, soy, and artificial colors, flavors, and preservatives. Opt for products with minimal additives and fillers to reduce the risk of adverse reactions and ensure purity.

Make sure the packaging and form of the medicine are easy to consume

Consider the packaging and form of the multivitamin. Choose formats that are convenient and easy to use, such as tablets, capsules, or soft gels. Ensure that the packaging is airtight and light-resistant to preserve the potency and stability of the nutrients. Individual packaging or blister packs can also help maintain freshness and convenience for on-the-go use.

Compare the cost and value

Evaluate the cost and value of the multivitamin based on the quality and quantity of nutrients provided. Compare prices across different brands and formulations to find the best value for your budget. Consider factors such as serving size, dosage, and nutrient content to determine the cost-effectiveness of the product. Remember that investing in high-quality multivitamins is an investment in your long-term health and wellbeing.

title: Start your day right! 5 foods to eat on an empty stomach - The Indian Express
mainText:
The way you begin your day sets the tone for the hours ahead, and choosing the right foods to kickstart your morning can have a significant impact on your overall health and well-being. Eating the right foods on an empty stomach can jumpstart your metabolism, provide essential nutrients, and boost your energy levels. Nutritionist Sakshi Lalwani took to Instagram to share five foods you can eat on an empty stomach to improve your health.

Jayfal or Nutmeg Powder
Nisha Mandal, consultant dietician, and nutritionist at Motherhood Hospitals, Gurgaon, tells indianexpress.com that consuming nutmeg powder on an empty stomach has several benefits.

“It is believed to aid digestion by stimulating the production of digestive enzymes and promoting gastric motility, which can help alleviate symptoms of indigestion and bloating. Nutmeg is rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory compounds, which may help boost immunity and reduce inflammation in the body when taken before meals,” she said.

Mandal noted that nutmeg should not be consumed empty stomach during pregnancy. However, being rich in dietary fibre, it can alleviate pregnancy-related discomfort.

She cautions that an overdose of nutmeg can lead to an upset gut and even intoxication. “A safe dosage would be 1 mg per day.”

Anjeer or Fig
According to Mandal, figs are high in fibre and contain vitamins and minerals such as potassium and calcium. “Consuming figs before breakfast may promote satiety and help control appetite throughout the day, making them a nutritious addition to your morning routine.”

Additionally, figs are advised to pregnant women as they are rich in iron, folate, and fibre, which support fetal development and prevent neural tube defects. “On an empty stomach, figs aid in better bowel movements and higher energy levels,” Mandal said.

Methi Dana (Fenugreek Seeds) and Ginger
While fenugreek seeds are known for their ability to regulate blood sugar levels and improve insulin sensitivity, ginger has anti-nausea and anti-inflammatory properties that can help soothe digestive discomfort.

“Together, methi dana and ginger can aid digestion, reduce bloating, and promote overall gut health when consumed on an empty stomach,” Mandal advised. However, pregnant women should steer clear of it on an empty stomach.

Haleem Seeds (Garden Cress Seeds)
Haleem seeds are packed with nutrients, including iron, calcium, and vitamins C and E, which are essential for maintaining healthy blood and bones. Additionally, haleem seeds are believed to have medicinal properties that can help improve respiratory health and boost immunity.

Mandal recommends consuming them before breakfast as it can enhance nutrient absorption and promote overall well-being. “Consuming it with vitamin C-rich fruits can aid digestion and increase absorption of iron from haleem seeds. One teaspoon of haleem seeds daily fulfills 60 per cent of the iron requirement, making it beneficial during pregnancy.”

Horse Gram Powder
Starting your day with horse gram powder can help regulate blood sugar levels, improve digestion, and promote weight loss due to its high fibre and low glycemic index. Horse gram also has a variety of medicinal and culinary benefits due to its protein and fibre-rich content.

title: The Mystery of Zombie Deer Disease: Alarming Truth Behind Chronic Wasting Disease Revealed! - BioTecNika
mainText:
Understanding Zombie Deer Disease: A Growing Concern in America

In the serene landscapes of North America’s forests and plains, a troubling trend called chronic wasting disease (CWD) is silently spreading among deer populations. This neurological condition, often referred to as “zombie deer disease,” is causing alarm among scientists, conservationists, and the general public due to its increasing prevalence.

The Mysterious Culprit: Prions At the core of the CWD issue lies a strange culprit known as prions. These misfolded proteins have the ability to cause normal proteins in the brain to misfold as well, resulting in neurological degeneration. What makes prion diseases especially worrisome is their resilience and ability to persist in the environment for extended periods, resisting conventional disinfection methods.

Health and Environmental Risks The spread of CWD not only poses ecological risks but also potential health risks for humans. While there is no definitive evidence of direct transmission to humans, prion diseases have been known to cross the species barrier with serious consequences. For instance, the outbreak of “mad cow disease” in Britain led to significant cattle slaughter and human deaths. While confirmed cases of CWD in humans are lacking, concerns remain due to the potential for transmission through hunting and consumption of infected animals.

Challenges in Detection and Diagnosis Detecting and diagnosing prion diseases in humans is inherently challenging due to the lack of immune response triggered by prions. This complicates early intervention efforts and highlights the need for improved detection methods to contain the spread of CWD.

Long-Term Implications on Human Health The persistence of prions in the environment means that humans could be indirectly exposed through contaminated soil, water, and other environmental sources. The long-term implications of CWD on human health remain uncertain but necessitate serious consideration due to the resilience of prions.

Ecological and Economic Impact Beyond health concerns, the proliferation of CWD poses significant risks to both ecosystems and economies. Deer hunting, a popular recreational activity and livelihood source, could be threatened by CWD, potentially disrupting food security in affected regions. Moreover, the decline in deer populations could have cascading effects on vegetation dynamics and other wildlife species dependent on deer.

International Considerations Although CWD outbreaks have not occurred in the UK, cases in Europe highlight the need for international cooperation in monitoring and controlling the disease. This emphasizes the importance of a comprehensive and coordinated approach to address the challenges posed by CWD.

Mitigating Risks and Protecting Wildlife To combat the threats posed by CWD, enhanced surveillance and monitoring, stringent biosecurity measures, and increased research efforts are essential.

author: Daily Pioneer
title: Consuming over 22 per cent protein daily may clog your arteries: Study - Daily Pioneer
mainText:
While eating protein is essential for good health, US researchers have discovered a molecular mechanism by which excessive dietary protein could increase the risk of atherosclerosis. Atherosclerosis is the build-up of fats, cholesterol, and other substances in and on the artery walls. The study, which combined small human trials with experiments in mice and cells in a Petri dish, showed that consuming over 22 per cent of dietary calories from protein can lead to increased activation of immune cells that play a role in atherosclerotic plaque formation, driving the disease risk. Furthermore, the scientists showed that one amino acid—leucine—seems to have a disproportionate role in driving the pathological pathways linked to atherosclerosis, or stiff, hardened arteries.

Babak Razani, Professor of cardiology at the University of Pittsburgh School of Medicine, emphasizes that dialing up protein intake in pursuit of better metabolic health is not a panacea. It could potentially cause real damage to your arteries. The hope is that this research starts a conversation about ways of modifying diets in a precise manner that can influence body function at a molecular level and dampen disease risks.

Previous studies have also shown that overreliance on protein may not be such a good thing for long-term health. Following their 2020 research, in which Razani’s laboratory first showed that excess dietary protein increases atherosclerosis risk in mice, his next study in collaboration with Bettina Mittendorfer, a metabolism expert at the University of Missouri, Columbia, delved deeper into the potential mechanism and its relevance to the human body. They demonstrated that amino acids, the building blocks of protein, can trigger disease through specific signaling mechanisms and alter the metabolism of cells. For instance, small immune cells in the vasculature called macrophages can trigger the development of atherosclerosis. Consuming more than 22 per cent of daily dietary calories through protein can negatively affect macrophages responsible for clearing out cellular debris, leading to the accumulation of a "graveyard" of those cells inside the vessel walls and worsening of atherosclerotic plaques over time. Interestingly, the analysis of circulating amino acids showed that leucine—an amino acid enriched in animal-derived foods like beef, eggs, and milk—is primarily responsible for abnormal macrophage activation and atherosclerosis risk, suggesting a potential avenue for further research on personalized diet modification, or "precision nutrition".

The findings are published in the journal Nature Metabolism. It’s crucial to consider these insights as we strive to balance our protein intake for overall health and well-being.

title: Weight Loss Diet Tips: 5 Foods to Eat Post Meal to Enhance Metabolism Rate - India.com
mainText:
Metabolism is an important aspect of weight loss. Adding these few foods in diet post meals can help boost metabolic rate helping to drop weight faster. These foods are:

1. Green Tea: Rich in antioxidants, green tea can enhance metabolism and promote fat oxidation. Drinking a cup of green tea after meals may aid in weight management.
2. Chili Peppers: Capsaicin, the compound responsible for the spiciness in chili peppers, can temporarily increase metabolic rate. Add some spicy peppers to your meal for a metabolism boost.
3. Protein-Rich Foods: Including protein in your post-meal diet can increase the thermic effect of food (TEF), which means your body burns more calories during digestion. Opt for lean protein sources like chicken, fish, tofu, or legumes.
4. Whole Grains: Whole grains provide complex carbohydrates and fiber, which help regulate blood sugar levels and prevent insulin spikes. This stability in blood sugar can positively impact metabolism.
5. Water: Staying hydrated is essential for efficient metabolism. Drinking water after meals aids digestion and supports metabolic processes.

Remember that while these foods can contribute to a healthier metabolism, overall dietary habits and physical activity play crucial roles in weight loss. Consult a registered dietitian or nutritionist for personalized advice and a well-balanced diet plan1.

author: Barkha Kumari
title: Doctors prescribe tips to keep respiratory infections at bay - Deccan Herald
mainText:
Bengaluru sees a rise in upper tract respiratory illnesses from mid-November to mid-February every year. However, some doctors told Metrolife the incidence was unusually higher this season. In many cases, cough and cold persisted for over a month, they said. The normal span is five to seven days. They attribute this to the chilly weather, weather change, dust, pollution, increased travelling, overcrowding during marriages, and even Covid. “The pollen season will last until early April. People with allergies need to be cautious,” says pulmonologist Dr Sachin Kumar. Experts share some preventive measures:

1. Focus on personal habits: Don’t touch dirty surfaces (such as used handkerchiefs) and then touch your mouth, eyes, or face. Washing your hands regularly, eating a balanced diet, getting physical activity, and clocking restful sleep are other suggestions.
2. Mask appropriately: Precautions advised during the Covid-19 pandemic still hold good. So, wear a mask in public or crowded places, sanitize your hands, follow coughing etiquette, and work from home when sick.
3. Check on vaccination: Adults often overlook vaccination. The flu shot is important for everyone, especially those with comorbidities like diabetes, immuno-compromised individuals, and those above the age of 65. It can lower the risk of viral infections. The two-shot pneumococcal vaccine can also protect against bacterial infections. Always consult your doctor before taking any shots.
4. Misconceptions: Drinking hot water regularly does not scientifically keep throat infections at bay. Staying hydrated is essential, whether with hot or normal water. However, daily steam inhalation may damage the surface lining of the windpipe and throat.

Remember to take these insights into account as you strive to maintain good respiratory health1.
